newsitem.title: INDIA: Indian banks credit-deposit ratio at 60.1 pct - RBI.
newsitem.headline: Indian banks credit-deposit ratio at 60.1 pct - RBI.

text.p: The credit to deposit ratio of banks in India as on last Friday of June 1996 amounted to 60.1 percent, the Reserve Bank of India (RBI) said on Tuesday.

"This ratio was relatively high for State Bank of India and its associates (72.2 percent), foreign banks (66.4 percent) and other scheduled commercial banks (65.9 percent)," RBI said in a press release.
The ratio was much lower for regional rural banks at 53 percent and nationalised banks at 52.9 percent. RBI did not give comparative figures for the year-ago period.
Metropolitan centres had the highest ratio of 78.3 percent followed by urban centres (50.6 percent), rural centres (46.9 percent) and semi-urban centres (39.1 percent).

Among the states, growth rate of deposits was the highest in Karnataka (25.5 percent) followed by Haryana (21.4 percent), Madhya Pradesh (19.8 percent), Bihar (19.1 percent), Assam (18.6 percent) and Rajasthan (18.4 percent).
The growth rate of bank credit was the highest in Karnataka (21.8 percent) followed by Madhya Pradesh (21.2 percent), Gujarat (21.1 percent), Tamil Nadu (19.6 percent) and Kerala (18.5 percent).

Six states comprising Maharashtra, Uttar Pradesh, West Bengal, Tamil Nadu, Gujarat and Andhra Pradesh together accounted for 55.7 percent share in aggregate deposits and 59.7 percent in gross bank credit. Maharashtra alone contributed 20.7 percent of total deposits and 25 percent of total credit.

Nationalised banks together contributed 55.1 percent of the aggregate deposits of all scheduled commercial banks, while State Bank of India and its associates accounted for another 26.5 percent. Shares of other bank groups were 7.7 percent for other scheduled commercial banks, 7.5 percent for foreign banks and 3.1 percent for regional rural banks.

In terms of bank credit, nationalised (state-run) banks accounted for a share of 48.6 percent of the total bank credit, while State Bank of India and its associates claimed a share of 31.9 percent. Other scheduled commercial banks, foreign banks and regional rural banks had shares of 8.5 percent, 8.3 percent and 2.8 percent respectively, RBI said.
